report_title: Major Smart Appliance Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: Major smart appliance manufacturers build smart household cooking appliances, refrigerators and laundry equipment. Revenue for the industry has surged during the current period because major smart appliances have become less expensive and more accessible to consumers, enabling manufacturers to sell to most households for the first time. Rising incomes during much of the current period also benefited the industry, as more money enabled consumers to purchase luxuries, such as major smart appliances.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Widespread Adoption of New Technology Has Driven Revenue Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As major smart appliances have become less expensive and more accessible, an increasing number of consumers have started to use them, boosting revenue growth. Revenue growth has been so rapid because the lack of market saturation has enabled manufacturers to find millions of first-time customers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 Caused More Households to Rely on Smart Cooking Appliances
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 forced people to stay home, so more people prepared their own food. Smart appliances make the cooking process easier, so demand for the industry's products soared during the pandemic, resulting in a massive increase in revenue in 2020.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Incomes Have Consistently Provided a Source of Demand for the Industry's Products
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: When consumers have more disposable income, spending rises on expensive products, such as major smart appliances. High wage growth in the years preceding the pandemic caused incomes to surge, benefiting the industry in 2018 and 2019. Massive government aid during COVID-19 gave consumers tons of cash. They used this money during the pandemic and the recovery to buy smart appliances, which raised revenue in 2020 and 2021.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: HIGH INPUT PRICES HAVE PROVIDED NEW REVENUE STREAMS FOR MANUFACTURERS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Wealthy consumers that purchase smart appliances are less sensitive to prices, so manufacturers can pass on the high costs of inputs to their buyers, raising their revenue. Supply chain disruptions have caused prices of key inputs (e.g. steel, plastic) to skyrocket during the pandemic recovery, causing revenue to soar in 2021. Buyers will eventually purchase traditional appliances if input prices become too high, so the industry can only benefit from higher costs up to a point.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: RISING INTEREST RATES HAVE INHIBITED DOWNSTREAM DEMAND
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Federal Reserve has raised interest rates in recent years to reduce inflation. As the cost of borrowing has risen, homebuying and residential construction have fallen. Since some consumers purchase major smart appliances when they build or buy a new home, the less active housing market has inhibited revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: STEADILY RISING INCOMES WILL BENEFIT MANUFACTURERS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite challenges from high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, GDP is anticipated to rise at a modest pace during the outlook period.

Interest rates will stay high during the outlook period, but consumers will eventually adjust to them, so homebuying and residential construction will pick up again as households accumulate more savings. Since the housing market is a major source of downstream demand for major smart appliance manufacturers, they'll benefit from the revived residential sector.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Depreciating Dollar Will Boost Demand From Foreign Markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The dollar is expected to depreciate during the outlook period. As the value of the dollar falls, domestically produced products become less expensive for buyers abroad. More foreigners will purchase US-produced smart appliances, providing an extra revenue stream for the industry.

Revenue soared during the current period because manufacturers were able to introduce their products to households for the first time. Many households will have already purchased major smart appliances by the mid-2020s, so the market for the industry's products will become saturated. Saturation makes it harder for manufacturers to find new customers, so revenue will increase at a much slower rate than during the current period.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry manufacture major smart household cooking appliances, refrigerators, freezers, laundry equipment and other major electrical and nonelectrical smart household appliances.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - steady

market_segmentation.segment_description: Wholesalers and retailers are major buyers of smart appliances, as their sales comprise more than four-tenths of the industry's revenue. Wholesalers sell major smart appliances from the industry and transfer them to retailers, which then sell them to the general population.

market_segmentation.segment: Building, heavy construction, special trade contractors
market_segmentation.segment_description: Building contractors and construction companies often buy smart appliances, as prospective homeowners want them to be automatically installed when purchasing a house.
Businesses also purchase smart appliances for end use in their own operations, as some products are useful in improving production processes.

market_segmentation.segment: Manufacturers for use as input goods in production
market_segmentation.segment_description: Major smart appliance manufacturers sell their goods to other manufacturers so they can use them as inputs in production. This can be for integrated home systems that combine multiple appliances.

Wholesalers and retailers are major buyers of smart appliances, as their sales comprise more than four-tenths of the industry's revenue. Retailers sell smart appliances from the industry to the general population.

products_and_services.product_description: Smart refrigerators and freezers integrate radio-frequency identification and barcode sensors into their design to keep track of their stock, enabling users to know when there's no more food in the fridge or when produce is about to spoil.

Smart cooking appliances include internet-enabled ovens, stoves, electric ranges, gas ranges and other cooking equipment and parts. One common feature in household cooking appliances is the use of voice-activated artificial assistant programs (e.g. Amazon Alexa, Google Assistant) to provide people with information regarding recipes, to set timers and to help in other ways.
Other smart appliances include Wi-Fi-enabled dishwashers, microwave ovens and other household items.
Smart laundry equipment enables users to start washing and drying machines through an app on a smartphone.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Rising Input Prices Have Boosted Demand for Smart Refrigerators and Freezers
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Supply chain disruptions have caused the price of plastic materials to soar. Companies have been able to pass on these high prices to consumers. Since smart refrigerators and freezers contain many plastics, their share of revenue has increased during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Steel Prices Have a Significant Impact on Revenue Received from Smart Laundry Equipment
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Since steel is a primary component in the manufacture of washers and dryers, its price is vital to the industry. The surging world price of steel has enabled companies to pass on these high prices to consumers, so smart laundry equipment's revenue share has crept upward during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Higher Incomes Have Increased Spending on Other Smart Appliances
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As per capita disposable income has increased, more consumers can afford these household goods, so other appliances' revenue share has risen during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand for Smart Cooking Appliances Surged During COVID-19 but Has Declined Recently
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for these appliances surged during COVID-19 since individuals were spending far more time at home but it has declined recently as people have been flocking back to the office.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The pandemic forced manufacturers to follow mask-wearing and social distancing regulations. These regulations made organizing assembly lines and plants more difficult, so production fell. To make up for this lost production, manufacturers imported more smart appliances in significant numbers.

The Trump administration imposed tariffs on China to encourage domestic production. These actions caused China to raise its tariffs, initiating a trade war. The trade war reduced imports from China drastically, altering the composition of where US consumers received the smart appliances from.

international_trade_points.trade_title: High-Interest Rates Have Battered Down Downstream Demand
international_trade_points.trade_description: The Federal Reserve has been raising interest rates to fight inflation. Since the cost of borrowing has risen, residential construction has fallen, reducing demand for smart appliances. Since demand for the industry's products has declined, so have imports.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The United States-Mexico-Canada (USMCA) Agreement Has Improved Ties With America's Partners
international_trade_points.trade_description: The USMCA was signed in 2019 and was made effective in 2020. The law reduced tariffs between the United States, Mexico and Canada for many goods, strengthening trade ties between the three North American countries. These provisions caused the share of exports of major smart appliances going to Mexico and Canada to rise.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The Industry Will Benefit From a Depreciating Dollar
international_trade_points.trade_description: The value of the US dollar is forecast to decrease during the outlook period. Smart appliances will become less expensive for consumers and companies abroad, so exports will surge, benefiting the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The West region contains the largest share of major smart appliance manufacturers, driven by California. Since California is home to Silicon Valley, where many residents are tech-savvy and seek to use new devices, raising demand for smart appliances and giving the industry a significant presence in the state.

States in the Great Lakes region, such as Illinois, Ohio and Michigan, contain many of the nation's biggest manufacturers. Since manufacturers are major buyers of smart appliances, there's a big incentive for the industry to locate there. Many manufacturers produce many key inputs for smart appliances (e.g. steel, plastic), so some companies locate there to be near suppliers.

The Southeast region contains states including Florida, Tennessee, North Carolina and Virginia. These states are large, so the region has the largest share of the country's population. The high population boosts demand for housing, increasing the need for smart appliances, so the industry has a major presence in the region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The CAA requires that companies comply with limits on the emission of pollutants. These rules apply to major smart appliance manufacturers because building new products can release chemicals that can pollute the air. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) applies allowances for the level of sulfur, nitrogen oxides, ozone and other pollutants companies can release into the atmosphere.

The CWA ensures that major smart appliance manufacturers don't pollute bodies of water. Since making smart appliances can create waste, companies might pollute streams of water if there isn't government regulation.

Smart appliances can collect personal data, such as usage patterns and preferences. Since consumers care about the protection of their private information, there are significant regulations on the collection and sharing of this data. Other regulations also force smart appliances to have systems in place to ensure they aren't hacked. This is to prevent third parties from finding the user's private information.
Major smart appliances must adhere to fire, electrical and other safety standards to ensure that they don't pose a risk to their users.

To ensure that COVID-19 didn't spread, governments forced manufacturers to enforce social distancing and mask-wearing laws. Major smart appliance makers had to adjust their procedures to follow these rules.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Revenue Volatility Level: very high, Industry Assistance Level: low - steady, Technology Change Level: high, Globalization Level: high - increasing, Competition Level: high - steady
Capital Intensity Level: low, Concentration Level: low

barriers_points.barrier_title: Costs of labor and capital as barriers
barriers_points.barrier_description: The costs of labor and capital provide notable barriers to entry for potential entrants. Capital intensity hinders the establishment of major smart appliance manufacturing companies more, as start-up costs for the machines, plants and other equipment used to build appliances are hefty.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition among major smart appliance manufacturers is high
basis_points.basis_description: The industry is composed of a few large players. These players primarily compete on price and quality.
The industry faces significant competition from imports. Threats from imports are dependent on exchange rates, supply chains and the cost of labor abroad.

concentration_points.concentration_title: High barriers to entry increase market share concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: It's costly to start up a major smart appliance manufacturing company, as it requires extensive investment in plants, assembly lines, technology, raw materials and workers. Manufacturers must also establish contracts with suppliers to remain competitive. Since barriers to entry are so high, many individuals decide not to set up shop, enabling large global players to control most of the industry.

Since most major players are international companies, they acquire corporations throughout the entire world. Major player Electrolux AB recently took over a French company called La Compagnie du SAV. While many acquisitions are of international companies, they enable big players to control the production of a specific product that's sometimes imported from abroad, reducing competition from foreign producers and raising concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PURCHASES HOLD STEADY DESPITE ECONOMIC CHALLENGES
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs are forecast to make up 50.6% of revenue in 2023. Purchases include raw materials, software and other items used to produce major smart appliances. Costs of these inputs have surged amid high inflation, but companies have been able to pass on many high prices to consumers, so purchase costs as a percentage of revenue have been stable during the current period.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: MISCELLANEOUS COSTS INCREASE AMID HIGH INFLATION
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Costs included in the "other" category are anticipated to comprise 28.0% of revenue. The cost of general administration, insurance and outsourced professional services are included in this category. High inflation has caused the costs of these services to increase. Since these services are used for manufacturers' benefit, they can't pass on these prices to consumers, so miscellaneous costs have risen as a percentage of revenue during the current period.

In 2023, profit is anticipated to comprise 6.8% of revenue. High-interest rates have reduced homebuying, reducing the need for major smart appliances. Declining downstream demand from the housing market has caused revenue and profit to fall in recent years.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: EMPLOYEES DEMAND MORE PAY AMID HIGHER INFLATION
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are anticipated to comprise 12.5% of revenue in 2023. As inflation has reduced workers' purchasing power, employees have been demanding higher wages. Under the threat that workers may flock to other companies, manufacturers have been raising their employees' pay, causing wages as a percentage of revenue to creep upward during the current period.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The costs of labor and capital provide notable barriers to entry for potential entrants.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital intensity hinders the establishment of major smart appliance manufacturing companies more, as start-up costs for the machines, plants and other equipment used to build appliances are hefty.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Shifting Input Prices Foster Volatility in the Industry
volatility_points.volatility_description: High input prices for materials, such as plastic and steel, are often beneficial for major smart appliance manufacturers, as they can pass on these high prices to consumers in many situations. Lower prices reduce this revenue stream for manufacturers, so they're damaging to the industry's performance. Supply chain disruptions and fluctuating demand resulting from COVID-19 and inflation have caused input prices to be unstable, enabling increased revenue volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Interest Rates Affect Downstream Demand from the Housing Market
volatility_points.volatility_description: Higher interest rates reduce homebuying, as the cost of borrowing is a major determinant of whether individuals decide to purchase property in a given year. Since homes are often installed with smart appliances, fewer homes being purchased inhibit downstream demand. Rates have fluctuated amid COVID-19 and high inflation because of the actions of the Federal Reserve, so they've increased volatility for the industry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: HIGH INCOMES BOOST SPENDING ON MAJOR SMART APPLIANCES
volatility_points.volatility_description: As incomes rise, consumers use more of their money to purchase luxuries, such as major smart appliances, benefiting the industry. Income growth has shifted significantly during the current period because of COVID-19, the pandemic recovery and government aid that was given out during that time period, creating more revenue volatility.

FAQs.answer: Being able to take advantage of economies of scale as a larger company is a strong advantage in terms of reducing production costs and being able to produce large quantities of inventory.
